From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Fri Jul 31 05:28:15 2009
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Fri Jul 31 05:28:20 2009
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour under OS/2 - eCS
In-Reply-To: <4A7288FB.3040903@mail.udg.mx>
References: <4A7288FB.3040903@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <20090731092815.GA30013@uran.home.aster.pl>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, David Arturo Macias Corona wrote:

Hi,

> >This looks like side effect caused by results of some previous builds.
> >It's possible that if you clean all files left by previous builds then
> >above warnings disappear. If it will not help then I would like to see
> >whole log file created for 'pp' directory.
> Is a fresh checkout, same warnings
> Below are partial content of make_ow.log from source dir to hbpp.lib
>
> make[3]: Entering directory 
> `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source/pp/obj/os2/watcom'
> wpp386 -zq -bt=OS2 -w3 -5r -fp5 -onaehtr -s -ei -zp4 -zt0 -oi+ -i. 
> -i../../../../../include   -DHB_FM_STATISTICS_OFF   ../../../hbpp.c 
> -fo=hbpp.obj
  ^^^^^^^^^^^^
> wlink sys OS2V2  NAME ../../../../../bin/os2/watcom/hbpp.exe FILE hbpp.obj 
> LIB ../../../../../lib/os2/watcom/hbcommon, 
> ../../../../../lib/os2/watcom/hbnortl
> Open Watcom Linker Version 1.8
> Portions Copyright (c) 1985-2002 Sybase, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
> Source code is available under the Sybase Open Watcom Public License.
> See http://www.openwatcom.org/ for details.
> loading object files
> searching libraries
> creating an OS/2 32-bit executable
> ../../../../../bin/os2/watcom/hbpp.exe ../../../../../include/hbstdgen.ch 
> -opptable.c -q -c../../../../../ -v../../../../../include/hbverbld.h
> Harbour Preprocessor 2.0.0beta2
> Copyright (c) 1999-2009, http://www.harbour-project.org/
> wpp386 -zq -bt=OS2 -w3 -5r -fp5 -onaehtr -s -ei -zp4 -zt0 -oi+ -i. 
> -i../../../../../include   -DHB_FM_STATISTICS_OFF   pptable.c 
> -fo=pptable.obj
> wpp386 -zq -bt=OS2 -w3 -5r -fp5 -onaehtr -s -ei -zp4 -zt0 -oi+ -i. 
> -i../../../../../include   -DHB_FM_STATISTICS_OFF   ../../../ppcore.c 
> -fo=ppcore.obj
[...]
> for %i in ( *.obj ) do @echo -+%i >> __lib__.tmp
            ^^^^^^^^^
> wlib -p=64 -c -n  @__lib__.tmp
> Open Watcom Library Manager Version 1.8
> Portions Copyright (c) 1984-2002 Sybase, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
> Source code is available under the Sybase Open Watcom Public License.
> See http://www.openwatcom.org/ for details.
> Warning! Duplicate symbol 'hb_pp_initRules_' ignored.
> Warning! Duplicate symbol 'hb_pp_tokenGet_' ignored.
> Warning! Duplicate symbol 'hb_pp_new_' ignored.
[...]
> rm hbpp.obj
> make[3]: Leaving directory `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source/pp/obj/os2/watcom'

As I wrote in one of previous messages this it's quite dangerous to use
code like:
   for %i in ( *$(OBJ_EXT) ) do @echo -+ %i >> __lib__.tmp
to create library and above situation exploited the problem.
Temporary file hbpp.obj created indirectly for hbpp.exe is added
to hbpp library. The same happens in GCC OS2 build though 'ar'
does not report above warnings.
I've just checked old messages between me and Maurilio and found why
it was added to os2/gcc.cf.
I can hardcode protection against it but instead of adding workaround
I would like to find cleaner way to create library without above
   for %i in ( *$(OBJ_EXT) ) do ...
in os2/gcc.cf and watcom.cf
The problem is caused by the GNU make 3.81 OS2 port. It GPFs with
original line:
   $(foreach file, $(^F), $(lib_object))
when the list of files is very long. Probably due insufficient memory
allocated for some operations and buffer overflow. There is question
if we can find workarond for it.

In a while I'll commit modifications to os2/watcom.cf which divided
list of library files into few smaller lists which should not exceed
1024 characters command line size limit in OS2.
Please test it.

best regards,
Przemek

From druzus at users.sourceforge.net  Fri Jul 31 05:32:12 2009

Date: Fri Jul 31 05:32:18 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11944] trunk/harbour
Message-ID: <E1MWoTE-0003sT-9Z@74yxhf1.ch3.sourceforge.com>

Revision: 11944
          http://harbour-project.svn.sourceforge.net/harbour-project/?rev=11944&view=rev
Author:   druzus
Date:     2009-07-31 09:32:11 +0000 (Fri, 31 Jul 2009)

Log Message:
-----------
2009-07-31 11:31 UTC+0200 Przemyslaw Czerpak (druzus/at/priv.onet.pl)
  * harbour/source/rtl/hbinet.c
    ! modified hb_inetRecv[All]() to always return number
      of bytes read if at least one byte was successfully read
      just like in documentation so it's not longer necessary to
      use hb_inetCount() to check real number of read bytes.
      On error they return -1 and 0 when foreign host closed connection.
    ! modified hb_inetSend[All]() to always return number of written
      bytes if at least one byte was successfully written so it's not
      longer necessary to use hb_inetCount() to check real number of
      written bytes. On error they return -1.
    ! modified hb_inetRecvLine() to return "" on errors and always
      set numeric value with error code or number of bytes read
      in 2-nd parameter passed by reference
    ! modified hb_inetDataReady() to return -1 instead of .F. to
      indicate errors when socket is not open socket
    ! modified  hb_inetRecvLine() and hb_inetRecvEndBlock() to work
      like in documentation and set in 2-nd parameter passed by
      reference the size of read line with line terminator, -1
      or error and 0 when foreign host closed connection.
    ! modified hb_inetRecvEndBlock() to always use default EOL when
      there is no not empty string in passed string parameter or
      passed array with line terminators
    ! fixed some small differences between hb_inetRecvLine() and
      hb_inetRecvEndBlock()
    ! fixed returned values in hb_InetDGramSend() and hb_InetDGramRecv()
      to be synced with documentation
    * minor: modified hb_inetRecvEndBlock() to use as default EOL
      s_inetCRLF instead of hardcoded "\r\n"
    * eliminated some redundant code
    + added automatic socket initialization in windows builds
    % added support for read ahead buffer in hb_inetRecvLine() and
      hb_inetRecvEndBlock() and updated other functions which may
      interact with it. It greatly improved the speed of code
      which extensively uses above functions.

   Warning!!! Above modifications may force updating other code which used
              some undocumented hb_inet*() functions behavior i.e. some side
              effects in previous implementation. Please update your code
              if necessary.

  * harbour/doc/inet.txt
    ! modified hb_inetAccept() documentation wrongly describing value
      returned on error when it's NIL

  * harbour/config/os2/watcom.cf
    ! fixes for real OS2 command processor - please test

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, vszakats@users.sourceforge.net wrote:

Hi,

> Log Message:
> -----------
> 2009-07-31 11:09 UTC+0200 Viktor Szakats (harbour.01 syenar.hu)
>   * include/hbdefs.h
>   * include/hbsetup.h

>   * source/vm/fm.c
>   + config/sunos/sunpro.cf
>     + Added first round of Sun Pro (Sun Studio) compiler.
>       Contribution of Tamas Tevesz.

Thanks guys :-)

>     ; TODO:
>       + Add other Sun Pro CPU targets.

I do not understand above. Most of *nixes builds can be compiled
with many different CPUs. The list of supported architectures
by such systems like Linux or *BSD is really huge. So far we
didn't have to replicate build configurations for each of them.
Why do you want to make some exceptions for SunOS? If we divide
configuration for different CPUs then we will end with hundreds
versions designed for each CPU.

>       * Finalize __inline keyword usage. (currently in fm.c)
>         Przemek, could you take a look at it?

Looks OK though for better performance in MT mode we should think
about adding some inline ASM code or better look for predefined
compiler functions for atomic operations.

best regards,
Przemek

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Fri Jul 31 06:02:25 2009
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Viktor_Szak=E1ts?=)
Date: Fri Jul 31 06:02:34 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
Message-ID: <C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>

>>    ; TODO:
>>      + Add other Sun Pro CPU targets.
>
> I do not understand above. Most of *nixes builds can be compiled
> with many different CPUs. The list of supported architectures
> by such systems like Linux or *BSD is really huge. So far we
> didn't have to replicate build configurations for each of them.
> Why do you want to make some exceptions for SunOS? If we divide
> configuration for different CPUs then we will end with hundreds
> versions designed for each CPU.

AFAIK SunPro has SPARC 32/64 and x86/x64 CPU targets. It can be
solved by simple few lines line long wrapper .cf files, so it won't
create any maintenance nightmare. For this reason I don't see this
is a problem at all in this case. It's however more convenient for
someone who wants to build for multiple CPU targets in parallel,
as continuous clean/rebuild phases can be avoided, saving a lot
of time. That's also the reason why I added separate 64 bit .cf
file for win platform, they are just few lines, but saved lots of
days worth of hours already just for me.

For Linux it may be different as the number of CPUs is larger,
anyhow probably only just a few are regularly used by Harbour
users in real life, so I think it would nice to have an x86-64
.cf even there.

>>      * Finalize __inline keyword usage. (currently in fm.c)
>>        Przemek, could you take a look at it?
>
> Looks OK though for better performance in MT mode we should think
> about adding some inline ASM code or better look for predefined
> compiler functions for atomic operations.

Okay, thank you.

Brgds,
Viktor

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Fri Jul 31 06:30:40 2009
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Fri Jul 31 06:30:46 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
Message-ID: <20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, Szak?ts Viktor wrote:

Hi,

> AFAIK SunPro has SPARC 32/64 and x86/x64 CPU targets. It can be
> solved by simple few lines line long wrapper .cf files, so it won't
> create any maintenance nightmare. For this reason I don't see this
> is a problem at all in this case. It's however more convenient for
> someone who wants to build for multiple CPU targets in parallel,
> as continuous clean/rebuild phases can be avoided, saving a lot
> of time.

I do not think so. In the moment when we added parallel processing in
GNU make with -j<n> switch then parallel build cannot give additional
speed improvement.

> That's also the reason why I added separate 64 bit .cf
> file for win platform, they are just few lines, but saved lots of
> days worth of hours already just for me.

I can understand that it can be useful but I do not like that in some
cases you are updating SVN for your own personal preferences creating
exactly the same problems you resolved for your own builds to other
developers.
Have you ever thought that removing linux/gpp.cf you created exactly the
same problem for me as you resolved for yourself adding win/mingw64.cf?
Now for my own use I have linux/gpp.cf and I do not commit it to SVN.
If each of us will commit his own extensions which simplifies build
process in our own configurations then it can create serious problems.
I strongly suggest to introduce common for all compilers and architectures
extension (SUBARCH) which can be used for all cases when we create
different binaries using the same base compiler, i.e. C/C++ mode,
different ABI or some compiler switches which change binary compatibility,
different CPU targets, etc instead of committing to SVN helpers for our
own local configurations and preferences.

best regards,
Przemek

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Fri Jul 31 06:43:45 2009
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Viktor_Szak=E1ts?=)
Date: Fri Jul 31 06:43:53 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
	<20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
Message-ID: <EA81B3D4-94CE-49FC-99B4-5C6EF770B06E@syenar.hu>

>> AFAIK SunPro has SPARC 32/64 and x86/x64 CPU targets. It can be
>> solved by simple few lines line long wrapper .cf files, so it won't
>> create any maintenance nightmare. For this reason I don't see this
>> is a problem at all in this case. It's however more convenient for
>> someone who wants to build for multiple CPU targets in parallel,
>> as continuous clean/rebuild phases can be avoided, saving a lot
>> of time.
>
> I do not think so. In the moment when we added parallel processing in
> GNU make with -j<n> switch then parallel build cannot give additional
> speed improvement.

You misunderstood me. I mean *having* two builds in parallel. And
simply doing incremental builds for both CPUs when source is updated.

>> That's also the reason why I added separate 64 bit .cf
>> file for win platform, they are just few lines, but saved lots of
>> days worth of hours already just for me.
>
> I can understand that it can be useful but I do not like that in some
> cases you are updating SVN for your own personal preferences creating
> exactly the same problems you resolved for your own builds to other
> developers.

I can't see how these can create problem. A lot of hbmk2 and distro
features would be missing without this move.

Please don't paint this as a personal feature. I don't use win64 for
*any* personal purpose. I did this to speed up and easy testing Harbour
for win64 platforms. That's all. Shame that I have to defend my
self all the time :(

> Have you ever thought that removing linux/gpp.cf you created exactly  
> the
> same problem for me as you resolved for yourself adding win/ 
> mingw64.cf?

Sorry I didn't. We can readd it if you need it, but to me a C++ and
C build are binary identical (at least they should be), so it doesn't
seem very useful to have or distribute them in parallel, at least for
most users. But I may be wrong.

> Now for my own use I have linux/gpp.cf and I do not commit it to SVN.
> If each of us will commit his own extensions which simplifies build
> process in our own configurations then it can create serious problems.
> I strongly suggest to introduce common for all compilers and  
> architectures
> extension (SUBARCH) which can be used for all cases when we create
> different binaries using the same base compiler, i.e. C/C++ mode,
> different ABI or some compiler switches which change binary  
> compatibility,
> different CPU targets, etc instead of committing to SVN helpers for  
> our
> own local configurations and preferences.

It's not my local preference.

My quick thought is that your solution is fully (meaning too) generic,
so such SUBARCH value wouldn't tell anything to hbmk2 or the GNU Make
system so it would only make things more complicated, and give benefit
for only very few users. I'd better like adding a HB_CPU sublevel  
instead.

I have to go now, but I'll think about it this afternoon.

Brgds,
Viktor

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Fri Jul 31 06:45:39 2009
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Fri Jul 31 06:45:45 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11947] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <E1MWpNu-0004dR-0B@dn4whf1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
References: <E1MWpNu-0004dR-0B@dn4whf1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
Message-ID: <20090731104539.GA4527@uran.home.aster.pl>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, vszakats@users.sourceforge.net wrote:

Hi,

> 2009-07-31 12:29 UTC+0200 Viktor Szakats (harbour.01 syenar.hu)
>   * source/rtl/hbinet.c
>     % Cleaned old error description handling logic. Now the error
>       desc is dynamically retrieved instead of being stored along
>       the error code.

It introduce very serious incompatibility to previous version
and eliminates important functionality: the error codes were
bound with sockets now we have single error code for all sockets
per thread.
It also creates other inconsistencies, i.e. some functions like
hb_inetServer() always returned socket so later then should be
used to test errors. Now such behavior is a nonsense so they
should be modified and documentation updated.

Please revert it. If you want then only modify the code to store
pointers to error descriptions instead of coping them to internal
buffer. Now they are all constant and comes from then same library
so we will not have problem if someone dynamically load and unload
some shared lib with constant strings.

best regards,
Przemek

From ice at wormhole.hu  Fri Jul 31 07:49:06 2009
From: ice at wormhole.hu (Tamas TEVESZ)
Date: Fri Jul 31 07:49:13 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
	<20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
Message-ID: <alpine.GSO.2.00.0907311347500.24971@dawn.royalcomp.hu>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, Przemyslaw Czerpak wrote:

hi,

 > > AFAIK SunPro has SPARC 32/64 and x86/x64 CPU targets. It can be
 > > solved by simple few lines line long wrapper .cf files, so it won't
 > > create any maintenance nightmare. For this reason I don't see this
 > > is a problem at all in this case. It's however more convenient for
 > > someone who wants to build for multiple CPU targets in parallel,
 > > as continuous clean/rebuild phases can be avoided, saving a lot
 > > of time.
 > 
 > I do not think so. In the moment when we added parallel processing in
 > GNU make with -j<n> switch then parallel build cannot give additional
 > speed improvement.

in reality, the split targets version looks like this:

sunpro64.cf: cflags = -m64
             include sunpro.cf
-- and that is all to a sunpro64.cf

sunpro.cf: cflags ?= -m32 # not really, but essentially that
-- other stuff in sunpro.cf

i don't think you can get any simpler than that. besides, it's not 
gcc, it doesn't (and probably won't ever) support anything more than 
sparc32/64 and x86/x64. at first i too thought of adding another knob 
to control whether one wants 32 or 64, but in the end i grew to like 
viktor's idea more.

how do you pick x64 target in, say, config/linux/gcc.cf? as far as i 
can tell, you don't. you either

- get what your toolchain defaults to
- you tweak the toolchain outside the build system
- tweak hb_user_cflags (which too is outside the build system)

all of these equally aren't very practical in the case where the same 
compiler (ie. definitely not a crosscompiler case) can target 32 and 
64 on the same host with the same toolchain.

 > I strongly suggest to introduce common for all compilers and architectures
 > extension (SUBARCH) which can be used for all cases when we create
 > different binaries using the same base compiler, i.e. C/C++ mode,
 > different ABI or some compiler switches which change binary compatibility,
 > different CPU targets, etc instead of committing to SVN helpers for our

which is different, how? you've just buried the same knobs deeper.

your way will be (much!) better in the long run, if and when hb itself 
will be retargetable (ie. say you have one hb installation on a mixed 
x86/x64 linux, and can tell the same hb to create 32-bit or 64-bit 
binaries), but at this very moment this seems pretty far.

not that i'd be very familiar with the build system, yet ;)

-- 
[-]

mkdir /nonexistent

From dmacias at mail.udg.mx  Fri Jul 31 08:09:06 2009
From: dmacias at mail.udg.mx (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Fri Jul 31 08:09:26 2009
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour under OS/2 - eCS
Message-ID: <4A72DEE2.3070505@mail.udg.mx>

 >As I wrote in one of previous messages this it's quite dangerous to use
 >code like:
 >   for %i in ( *$(OBJ_EXT) ) do @echo -+ %i >> __lib__.tmp
 >to create library and above situation exploited the problem.
 >Temporary file hbpp.obj created indirectly for hbpp.exe is added
 >to hbpp library. The same happens in GCC OS2 build though 'ar'
 >does not report above warnings.
 >I've just checked old messages between me and Maurilio and found why
 >it was added to os2/gcc.cf.
 >I can hardcode protection against it but instead of adding workaround
 >I would like to find cleaner way to create library without above
 >   for %i in ( *$(OBJ_EXT) ) do ...
 >in os2/gcc.cf and watcom.cf
 >The problem is caused by the GNU make 3.81 OS2 port. It GPFs with
 >original line:
 >   $(foreach file, $(^F), $(lib_object))
 >when the list of files is very long. Probably due insufficient memory
 >allocated for some operations and buffer overflow. There is question
 >if we can find workarond for it.

 >In a while I'll commit modifications to os2/watcom.cf which divided
 >list of library files into few smaller lists which should not exceed
 >1024 characters command line size limit in OS2.
 >Please test it.

 >  * harbour/config/os2/watcom.cf
 >    ! fixes for real OS2 command processor - please test

Current Harbour under OS/2
  * $Id: ChangeLog 11949 2009-07-31 11:21:30Z druzus $
2009-07-31 13:21 UTC+0200 Przemyslaw Czerpak (druzus/at/priv.onet.pl)

It fail with:
--------------------------------
make[3]: *** [hbrtl.lib] Segmentation fault
make[2]: *** [descend] Error 2
make[1]: *** [rtl] Error 2
make: *** [source] Error 2
--------------------------------

and make_ow.log contain:

--------------------------------
wpp386 -zq -bt=OS2 -w3 -5r -fp5 -onaehtr -s -ei -zp4 -zt0 -oi+ -i. 
-i../../../../../include   -DHB_FM_STATISTICS_OFF   wait.c -fo=wait.obj
echo ../../../../../lib/os2/watcom/hbrtl.lib > __lib__.tmp
make[3]: Leaving directory 
`E:/harbour907e/harbour/source/rtl/obj/os2/watcom'
make[2]: Leaving directory `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source/rtl'
make[1]: Leaving directory `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source'
--------------------------------

As old failure, can not create and fill __lib__.tmp

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Fri Jul 31 08:45:04 2009
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Fri Jul 31 08:45:11 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <alpine.GSO.2.00.0907311347500.24971@dawn.royalcomp.hu>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
	<20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<alpine.GSO.2.00.0907311347500.24971@dawn.royalcomp.hu>
Message-ID: <20090731124503.GB7997@uran.home.aster.pl>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, Tamas TEVESZ wrote:

Hi,

> sunpro64.cf: cflags = -m64
>              include sunpro.cf
> -- and that is all to a sunpro64.cf
> sunpro.cf: cflags ?= -m32 # not really, but essentially that
> -- other stuff in sunpro.cf

Yes it is but these flags are useful only if you want to overwrite
default platform settings.
Just like for x86 CPU we can use -march=native,i386,i486,i586,i686,
pentium2,pentium3,pentium4,prescott,nocona,core2,k6,k6-2,athlon,
athlon-xp,opteron,opteron-sse3,amdfam10,geode,... and also -m32/-m64
All this CPU uses different instructions sets so optimized code
does not have to be portable between platforms or at least is not
optimal.
And this is only x86 family. There are also other compiler switches
which can cause that generated code is not binary compatible f.e.
alignment switches or switches to control calling convention (ABI)
like passing parameters by stack or registers in OpwnWatcom builds.
Farther I can use different CRTLs for cross builds, i.e. I'm building
Harbour with uclibc for some embedded systems or disk less client
stations. Should I create new .cf files for each possible combination?
And what about cross compilation to other architectures.
For all posisble combinations we will have to creat hundreds of .cf files.
I can collect all my different build scripts and commit them to SVN as new
.cf files. Can you tell me what will be your and other developers reaction?

> i don't think you can get any simpler than that. besides, it's not 
> gcc, it doesn't (and probably won't ever) support anything more than 
> sparc32/64 and x86/x64. at first i too thought of adding another knob 
> to control whether one wants 32 or 64, but in the end i grew to like 
> viktor's idea more.

I do not agree because you arbitrary chose the combination you need
personally. For other people other combinations can be more important.
I.e. cross compilation for ARMS, MISC or compilation with uclibc.

> how do you pick x64 target in, say, config/linux/gcc.cf? as far as i 
> can tell, you don't. you either

   export PATH="...:$PATH"
   export HB_USER_CFLAGS=...
   export HB_USER_LDFLAGS=...
   export HB_USER_AFLAGS=...

and to make things more funny I have biggest problem with 3-rd party
tools header auto detection we added recently because it locates my
native tools. Fortunately I can use HB_XBUILD to disable most of them.
Anyhow it's the fact that I have to reduce the frequency of SVN
synchronizations in my production environment because I always had
to update sth after such synchronization.

> - get what your toolchain defaults to
> - you tweak the toolchain outside the build system
> - tweak hb_user_cflags (which too is outside the build system)

I do not understand.

> all of these equally aren't very practical in the case where the same 
> compiler (ie. definitely not a crosscompiler case) can target 32 and 
> 64 on the same host with the same toolchain.

AFAIK using user custom build flag is the only one practical solution
and it's the reason why we have it. Adding new .cf files because some
developers likes or use some configuration is IMHO bad idea.

>  > I strongly suggest to introduce common for all compilers and architectures
>  > extension (SUBARCH) which can be used for all cases when we create
>  > different binaries using the same base compiler, i.e. C/C++ mode,
>  > different ABI or some compiler switches which change binary compatibility,
>  > different CPU targets, etc instead of committing to SVN helpers for our
> which is different, how? you've just buried the same knobs deeper.

See above.

> your way will be (much!) better in the long run, if and when hb itself 
> will be retargetable (ie. say you have one hb installation on a mixed 
> x86/x64 linux, and can tell the same hb to create 32-bit or 64-bit 
> binaries), but at this very moment this seems pretty far.

I have few customized installations in single production system and
it's normal for me that I expect that such functionality will work
in Harbour and I do not want to force my own personal preferences.
But I also want to keep build scripts as simple as possible so I can
easy adopt them to any cross compilation settings.

> not that i'd be very familiar with the build system, yet ;)

I hope you will be soon :-). I use SunOS really seldom and each time
I have to work with this OS I'm finding a lot of GNU only extensions
I used to use unintentionally, i.e.:
   find -name "*.cf"
ups - it does not work in SunOS, etc.
We really need someone who is using regularly some more restrictive
POSIX environment.

best regards,
Przemek
From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Fri Jul 31 09:04:22 2009
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Fri Jul 31 09:04:28 2009
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour under OS/2 - eCS

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, David Arturo Macias Corona wrote:

Hi,

> Current Harbour under OS/2
>  * $Id: ChangeLog 11949 2009-07-31 11:21:30Z druzus $
> 2009-07-31 13:21 UTC+0200 Przemyslaw Czerpak (druzus/at/priv.onet.pl)
> It fail with:
> --------------------------------
> and make_ow.log contain:
> --------------------------------
> wpp386 -zq -bt=OS2 -w3 -5r -fp5 -onaehtr -s -ei -zp4 -zt0 -oi+ -i. 
> -i../../../../../include   -DHB_FM_STATISTICS_OFF   wait.c -fo=wait.obj
> echo ../../../../../lib/os2/watcom/hbrtl.lib > __lib__.tmp
> make[3]: Leaving directory 
> `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source/rtl/obj/os2/watcom'
> make[2]: Leaving directory `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source/rtl'
> make[1]: Leaving directory `E:/harbour907e/harbour/source'
> --------------------------------
> As old failure, can not create and fill __lib__.tmp

Thank you for your test.
In current os2/watcom.cf I added this lines to create libraries.

# maximum size of command line in OS2 is limited to 1024 characters
# the trick below with 'wordlist' is workaround for it
define create_library
echo $(LIB_DIR)/$@ > __lib__.tmp
$(if $(wordlist   1, 50,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist   1, 50,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  51,100,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  51,100,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist 101,150,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist 101,150,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist 151,200,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist 151,200,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist 201,250,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist 201,250,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist 250,300,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist 250,300,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist 300,999,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist 300,999,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(AR) $(ARFLAGS) @__lib__.tmp
endef

Looks that it's not enough for OS2 GNU make 3.81 and it still GPFs.
So I will have to ask you to make some tests to locate what exactly
exploits the bug.
If it's single line size the we have a chance to create workaround for it.
If it's caused by total length of all commands then I'm afraid we cannot
resolve it in such way.
Please try to remove few lines from above command and reduce it to:

define create_library
echo $(LIB_DIR)/$@ > __lib__.tmp
$(if $(wordlist   1, 50,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist   1, 50,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  51,100,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  51,100,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(AR) $(ARFLAGS) @__lib__.tmp
endef

and check if GPFs is gone (of course RTL library create in such way will
be uncomplited but it can give us important answer about the reason of
problem.
If it will still GPF then you can try to reduce single line length, i.e.

define create_library
echo $(LIB_DIR)/$@ > __lib__.tmp
$(if $(wordlist   1, 20,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist   1, 20,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  21, 40,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  21, 40,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  41, 60,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  41, 60,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  61, 80,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  61, 80,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  81,100,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  81,100,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(AR) $(ARFLAGS) @__lib__.tmp
endef

If it still generates GPF then you can finally try sth like:
define create_library
echo $(LIB_DIR)/$@ > __lib__.tmp
$(if $(wordlist   1, 10,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist   1, 10,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  11, 20,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  11, 20,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(if $(wordlist  21, 30,$(^F)), echo $(wordlist  21, 30,$(addprefix -+,$(^F))) >> __lib__.tmp,)
$(AR) $(ARFLAGS) @__lib__.tmp
endef

your results should help in locating the exact reason of problem.

best regards,
Przemek

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Fri Jul 31 09:59:54 2009
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?UTF-8?Q?Viktor_Szak=C3=A1ts?=)

Subject: [Harbour] Re: SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour

Citing "personal reason" is totally wrong. Unless messing/having fun
with harbour counts as such. Please stop using this argument. Or i can
drop dealing with every component which i dont use, this means about
90% of them. Imo we should allow such configs if possible, but the
focus should be on scenarios which may be useful for multiple users in
practice, and making these easy to use (as opposed to *all
theoretically possible* combinations). Msvc64.cf is one example. I can
delete it, but you will notice huge drop in quality of this port, drop
from binary distro and no more testing on my system.

On 7/31/09, Przemyslaw Czerpak <druzus@acn.waw.pl> wrote:
> On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, Tamas TEVESZ wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
>> sunpro64.cf: cflags = -m64
>>              include sunpro.cf
>> -- and that is all to a sunpro64.cf
>> sunpro.cf: cflags ?= -m32 # not really, but essentially that
>> -- other stuff in sunpro.cf
>
> Yes it is but these flags are useful only if you want to overwrite
> default platform settings.
> Just like for x86 CPU we can use -march=native,i386,i486,i586,i686,
> pentium2,pentium3,pentium4,prescott,nocona,core2,k6,k6-2,athlon,
> athlon-xp,opteron,opteron-sse3,amdfam10,geode,... and also -m32/-m64
> All this CPU uses different instructions sets so optimized code
> does not have to be portable between platforms or at least is not
> optimal.
> And this is only x86 family. There are also other compiler switches
> which can cause that generated code is not binary compatible f.e.
> alignment switches or switches to control calling convention (ABI)
> like passing parameters by stack or registers in OpwnWatcom builds.
> Farther I can use different CRTLs for cross builds, i.e. I'm building
> Harbour with uclibc for some embedded systems or disk less client
> stations. Should I create new .cf files for each possible combination?
> And what about cross compilation to other architectures.
> For all posisble combinations we will have to creat hundreds of .cf files.
> I can collect all my different build scripts and commit them to SVN as new
> .cf files. Can you tell me what will be your and other developers reaction?
>
>> i don't think you can get any simpler than that. besides, it's not
>> gcc, it doesn't (and probably won't ever) support anything more than
>> sparc32/64 and x86/x64. at first i too thought of adding another knob
>> to control whether one wants 32 or 64, but in the end i grew to like
>> viktor's idea more.
>
> I do not agree because you arbitrary chose the combination you need
> personally. For other people other combinations can be more important.
> I.e. cross compilation for ARMS, MISC or compilation with uclibc.
>
>> how do you pick x64 target in, say, config/linux/gcc.cf? as far as i
>> can tell, you don't. you either
>
>    export PATH="...:$PATH"
>    export HB_USER_CFLAGS=...
>    export HB_USER_LDFLAGS=...
>    export HB_USER_AFLAGS=...
>
> and to make things more funny I have biggest problem with 3-rd party
> tools header auto detection we added recently because it locates my
> native tools. Fortunately I can use HB_XBUILD to disable most of them.
> Anyhow it's the fact that I have to reduce the frequency of SVN
> synchronizations in my production environment because I always had
> to update sth after such synchronization.
>
>> - get what your toolchain defaults to
>> - you tweak the toolchain outside the build system
>> - tweak hb_user_cflags (which too is outside the build system)
>
> I do not understand.
>
>> all of these equally aren't very practical in the case where the same
>> compiler (ie. definitely not a crosscompiler case) can target 32 and
>> 64 on the same host with the same toolchain.
>
> AFAIK using user custom build flag is the only one practical solution
> and it's the reason why we have it. Adding new .cf files because some
> developers likes or use some configuration is IMHO bad idea.
>
>>  > I strongly suggest to introduce common for all compilers and
>> architectures
>>  > extension (SUBARCH) which can be used for all cases when we create
>>  > different binaries using the same base compiler, i.e. C/C++ mode,
>>  > different ABI or some compiler switches which change binary
>> compatibility,
>>  > different CPU targets, etc instead of committing to SVN helpers for our
>> which is different, how? you've just buried the same knobs deeper.
>
> See above.
>
>> your way will be (much!) better in the long run, if and when hb itself
>> will be retargetable (ie. say you have one hb installation on a mixed
>> x86/x64 linux, and can tell the same hb to create 32-bit or 64-bit
>> binaries), but at this very moment this seems pretty far.
>
> I have few customized installations in single production system and
> it's normal for me that I expect that such functionality will work
> in Harbour and I do not want to force my own personal preferences.
> But I also want to keep build scripts as simple as possible so I can
> easy adopt them to any cross compilation settings.
>
>> not that i'd be very familiar with the build system, yet ;)
>
> I hope you will be soon :-). I use SunOS really seldom and each time
> I have to work with this OS I'm finding a lot of GNU only extensions
> I used to use unintentionally, i.e.:
>    find -name "*.cf"
> ups - it does not work in SunOS, etc.
> We really need someone who is using regularly some more restrictive
> POSIX environment.
>
> best regards,
> Przemek

> freeze, and segmentation fault happen building librtl.a ( in current case, 
> hbrtl.lib )
> So is an older problem with make.exe in OS/2, either with gcc or watcom as 
> you said

Yes and it's a bug in OS2 GNU make port we are exploiting from time to time.
If we find some acceptable solution the we will use it. If not we will
have to return to the:
   for %i in ( *$(OBJ_EXT) ) do @echo ... >> __lib__.tmp
trick and add some hack to protect against adding hbpp.obj to library.

Though we can also try to disable rules for parallel processing.
They will reduce total number of used rules so maybe it's good
workaround for the memory overflow.
If you add at config/dir.cf[19]:

   JOB_SRV := NO

just before:

   ifeq ($(JOB_SRV),NO)

then you disable parallel processing rules.

> Actually I am not using third case of make.exe, just second case
> Same error with make.exe (3.81) of Viktor Szakats (second case with static 
> build)

BTW what happens when you tries to use older make (3.7x) with current SVN
code?

best regards,
Przemek
From ice at wormhole.hu  Fri Jul 31 11:08:38 2009
From: ice at wormhole.hu (Tamas TEVESZ)
Date: Fri Jul 31 11:08:45 2009
Subject: [Harbour] SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <20090731124503.GB7997@uran.home.aster.pl>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
	<20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<alpine.GSO.2.00.0907311347500.24971@dawn.royalcomp.hu>
	<20090731124503.GB7997@uran.home.aster.pl>
Message-ID: <alpine.GSO.2.00.0907311647350.24971@dawn.royalcomp.hu>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, Przemyslaw Czerpak wrote:


i certainly feel your pain, and you do have a valid point, but so do 
i.

face it, you are a  special breed, besides doing stuff in harbour, you 
also know a metric shitload of toolchains and platforms inside out, 
and want to make use of that knowledge, when doing stuff in harbour 
itself. this is fine, and understandable, maybe desired even. your 
tinkering pushes the project forward.

but you are the exception. the majority just *uses* harbour, and they 
couldn't care less what compiler settings hb was compiled with, or was 
it compiled with gcc, icc, acc, or whatever. for this user class, 
there *have* to be *sane defaults*. these users won't know -KPIC from 
-xarch=v8, and they don't need to. sane defaults provide that. they 
just make_gnu.sh, and happily use the result to do what they do, 
develop *in* harbour. not develop harbour. sane defaults for the 
average user. putting knobs everywhere at that level is bad. very.

this clashes with your need to tinker because of one single reason: 
the build system never was designed for supporting such a number of 
platforms, it just grew organically. while it would be needed, it 
simply can't, at the same time, support both sane defaults and allow 
for completely turning every last option inside out.

i don't like this either, and have numerous other problems, too; but 
while definitely am willing to cough something better up, at the end 
of the day i still can only do one thing at a time.

here's my compromise: you've lived with that long enough. live with 
that some more, let me finish sunpro/solaris (and maybe sunpro/linux 
as a byproduct, i don't expect them to be all that different) using 
this current methodology. when it gets to an acceptable shape, i'll 
gradually shift my focus towards the build system itself.

this won't cause you any more headaches you currently have (granted, 
won't lessen them either), but allows me to figure out the current 
build system, which means me better understanding what needs to be 
redone.

of course this won't happen overnight, but at least i'm stepping up.

 > We really need someone who is using regularly some more restrictive
 > POSIX environment.
 
i'm quite good at that, too :)


 > > sunpro64.cf: cflags = -m64
 > >              include sunpro.cf
 > > -- and that is all to a sunpro64.cf
 > > sunpro.cf: cflags ?= -m32 # not really, but essentially that
 > > -- other stuff in sunpro.cf
 > 
 > Yes it is but these flags are useful only if you want to overwrite
 > default platform settings.
 > Just like for x86 CPU we can use -march=native,i386,i486,i586,i686,
 > pentium2,pentium3,pentium4,prescott,nocona,core2,k6,k6-2,athlon,
 > athlon-xp,opteron,opteron-sse3,amdfam10,geode,... and also -m32/-m64
 > All this CPU uses different instructions sets so optimized code
 > does not have to be portable between platforms or at least is not
 > optimal.
 > And this is only x86 family. There are also other compiler switches
 > which can cause that generated code is not binary compatible f.e.
 > alignment switches or switches to control calling convention (ABI)
 > like passing parameters by stack or registers in OpwnWatcom builds.
 > Farther I can use different CRTLs for cross builds, i.e. I'm building
 > Harbour with uclibc for some embedded systems or disk less client
 > stations. Should I create new .cf files for each possible combination?
 > And what about cross compilation to other architectures.
 > For all posisble combinations we will have to creat hundreds of .cf files.
 > I can collect all my different build scripts and commit them to SVN as new
 > .cf files. Can you tell me what will be your and other developers reaction?
 > 
 > > i don't think you can get any simpler than that. besides, it's not 
 > > gcc, it doesn't (and probably won't ever) support anything more than 
 > > sparc32/64 and x86/x64. at first i too thought of adding another knob 
 > > to control whether one wants 32 or 64, but in the end i grew to like 
 > > viktor's idea more.
 > 
 > I do not agree because you arbitrary chose the combination you need
 > personally. For other people other combinations can be more important.
 > I.e. cross compilation for ARMS, MISC or compilation with uclibc.
 > 
 > > how do you pick x64 target in, say, config/linux/gcc.cf? as far as i 
 > > can tell, you don't. you either
 > 
 >    export PATH="...:$PATH"
 >    export HB_USER_CFLAGS=...
 >    export HB_USER_LDFLAGS=...
 >    export HB_USER_AFLAGS=...
 > 
 > and to make things more funny I have biggest problem with 3-rd party
 > tools header auto detection we added recently because it locates my
 > native tools. Fortunately I can use HB_XBUILD to disable most of them.
 > Anyhow it's the fact that I have to reduce the frequency of SVN
 > synchronizations in my production environment because I always had
 > to update sth after such synchronization.
 > 
 > > - get what your toolchain defaults to
 > > - you tweak the toolchain outside the build system
 > > - tweak hb_user_cflags (which too is outside the build system)
 > 
 > I do not understand.
 > 
 > > all of these equally aren't very practical in the case where the same 
 > > compiler (ie. definitely not a crosscompiler case) can target 32 and 
 > > 64 on the same host with the same toolchain.
 > 
 > AFAIK using user custom build flag is the only one practical solution
 > and it's the reason why we have it. Adding new .cf files because some
 > developers likes or use some configuration is IMHO bad idea.
 > 
 > >  > I strongly suggest to introduce common for all compilers and architectures
 > >  > extension (SUBARCH) which can be used for all cases when we create
 > >  > different binaries using the same base compiler, i.e. C/C++ mode,
 > >  > different ABI or some compiler switches which change binary compatibility,
 > >  > different CPU targets, etc instead of committing to SVN helpers for our
 > > which is different, how? you've just buried the same knobs deeper.
 > 
 > See above.
 > 
 > > your way will be (much!) better in the long run, if and when hb itself 
 > > will be retargetable (ie. say you have one hb installation on a mixed 
 > > x86/x64 linux, and can tell the same hb to create 32-bit or 64-bit 
 > > binaries), but at this very moment this seems pretty far.
 > 
 > I have few customized installations in single production system and
 > it's normal for me that I expect that such functionality will work
 > in Harbour and I do not want to force my own personal preferences.
 > But I also want to keep build scripts as simple as possible so I can
 > easy adopt them to any cross compilation settings.
 > 
 > > not that i'd be very familiar with the build system, yet ;)
 > 
 > I hope you will be soon :-). I use SunOS really seldom and each time
 > I have to work with this OS I'm finding a lot of GNU only extensions
 > I used to use unintentionally, i.e.:
 >    find -name "*.cf"
 > ups - it does not work in SunOS, etc.
 > We really need someone who is using regularly some more restrictive
 > POSIX environment.
 > 
 > best regards,
 > Przemek
 > _______________________________________________
 > Harbour mailing list
 > Harbour@harbour-project.org
 > http://lists.harbour-project.org/mailman/listinfo/harbour
 >

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Fri Jul 31 11:15:01 2009
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Fri Jul 31 11:15:07 2009
Subject: [Harbour] Re: SF.net SVN: harbour-project:[11942] trunk/harbour
In-Reply-To: <18d502870907310659o1a752f86g324c13038da027d0@mail.gmail.com>
References: <E1MWoA7-0005CA-6B@d5vjzd1.ch3.sourceforge.com>
	<20090731095413.GA27826@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<C676304E-916B-442E-8389-2D3F6215423D@syenar.hu>
	<20090731103040.GA1844@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<alpine.GSO.2.00.0907311347500.24971@dawn.royalcomp.hu>
	<20090731124503.GB7997@uran.home.aster.pl>
	<18d502870907310659o1a752f86g324c13038da027d0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20090731151501.GA17046@uran.home.aster.pl>

On Fri, 31 Jul 2009, Szak?ts Viktor wrote:
> Citing "personal reason" is totally wrong. Unless messing/having fun
> with harbour counts as such. Please stop using this argument. Or i can
> drop dealing with every component which i dont use, this means about
> 90% of them. Imo we should allow such configs if possible, but the
> focus should be on scenarios which may be useful for multiple users in
> practice, and making these easy to use (as opposed to *all
> theoretically possible* combinations). Msvc64.cf is one example. I can
> delete it, but you will notice huge drop in quality of this port, drop
> from binary distro and no more testing on my system.

Sorry that you do not like "personal reason". It's not my intention
to be rude.
So let's say that _MY_OWN_ personal preferences are much too different
then current SVN code and I have to introduce more or less intrusive
modifications to use Harbour as I want. So I would like to ask you
only about one single functionality.
On each POSIX platform it should be possible to simply type
   make
without any environment variable set also without HB_ARCHITECTURE
(use HB_HOST_ARCH as default) and HB_COMPILER (some arbitrary choices
based on HB_HOST_ARCH maybe with minor detection). Of course user
if want can still set HB_ARCHITECTURE and HB_COMPILER manually.
The default for given platform compiler should not set even single
architecture dependent option and use only default settings and some
general optimization switches like -O3 in GCC.
All other switches can be set by HB_USER_*FLAGS envvars if necessary.
I also want ask to add support for new environment variable which
can be used as part of ARCH_COMP, i.e.:
   ARCH_COMP := $(HB_ARCHITECTURE)/$(HB_COMPILER)$(HB_BILD_SIG)
Above modifications will make me really happy and I'll migrate with
my private harbour build settings to use such basic build settings
and I will not have to update my build scripts after each 'svn update'
Then you can add as much .cf file for different os/compiler/cpu/crtl
combinations as you want or you feel other developers want/need.

best regards,
Przemek
